bestBHT.bht: Take heed and be cautious, for the example of the Israelites is a warning against complacency within the community of believers. Our security consists in faith and fear, as the danger lies in being self-assured in one's faith. Do not boast or forget your weakness, as it can lead to falling into sin. Instead, find assurance in the promises of God and remain vigilant, lest you fall from your place in the Church of God.

Henry Alford: To such an one the example of the Israelites is a warning to take heed that he fall not."
He standeth, viz. in his place as a member of Christ’s church, to be recognized by him at His coming for one of His.
...as they did from their place in God’s church.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: stands and thinks that he stands" - The commentary highlights the danger of being self-assured in one's faith.
fell from his place in the Church of God" - This quote emphasizes the consequence of complacency within the community of believers.
Our security [...] consists in faith; so far as relates to ourselves, it consists in fear." - The statement underscores the role of faith and fear in our sense of security with God and ourselves.
Albert Barnes: A confidence in our own security is no evidence that we are safe.
Those are most safe who feel that they are weak and feeble, and who feel their need of divine aid and strength.
Christians in their favored moments, when they are permitted to approach near to God, should exercise special caution.
John Calvin: For the Corinthians gloried in their condition in such a way, that, forgetting their weakness, they fell into many crimes.
The one is that which rests on the promises of God, because a pious conscience feels assured that God will never be wanting to it...
This kind of assurance is sacred, and is inseparable from faith, as appears from many passages of Scripture, and especially Romans 8:33.
Philip Schaff: Our greatest danger lies in a presumptuous confidence of our safety.
Our true safety will be found in a humble distrust of ourselves.
Our true safety will be found in continual watchfulness.
Archibald T. Robertson: Lest he fall (μη πεση). Negative purpose with μη and second aorist active subjunctive of πιπτω.
John Gill: everyone of these should take heed lest he fall.
John Wesley: The common translation runs, Let him that thinketh he standeth; but the word translated thinketh, most certainly strengthens, rather than weakens, the sense.

bhtAttempts.bht: Beware of becoming too confident in your faith, for the example of the Israelites serves as a warning against complacency in the church. Our security is not found in our own self-assurance, but rather in our faith and fear - a humble recognition of our weakness and need for divine aid. Christians, especially when drawing close to God, should exercise caution and continual watchfulness. Do not boast in your condition, for forgetting your weakness can lead to falling into many sins. Instead, find assurance in the promises of God and remain vigilant, lest you too should fall from your place in the Church of God.

Take heed and be cautious, for the example of the Israelites is a warning against complacency in the church. Beware of being self-assured in your faith, as our security lies in faith and fear. Christians should exercise caution and continual watchfulness, especially when drawing near to God. Do not boast, as forgetting your weakness can lead to falling into sin. Instead, find assurance in God's promises and remain vigilant, lest you too fall from your place in the Church of God.

Beware of complacency and self-assurance in your faith, for the example of the Israelites is a warning. Our security is rooted in faith and fear, not in our own confidence. Christians should exercise caution, remaining watchful and humble. Don't boast, as forgetting your weakness can lead to sin. Instead, find assurance in God's promises and remain vigilant, lest you fall from your place in the Church of God.

Take heed and be cautious, for the example of the Israelites is a warning against complacency within the community of believers. Our security consists in faith and fear, as the danger lies in being self-assured in one's faith. Do not boast or forget your weakness, as it can lead to falling into sin. Instead, find assurance in the promises of God and remain vigilant, lest you fall from your place in the Church of God.

To avoid falling, one must take heed of the warning provided by the example of the Israelites. The danger lies in being self-assured and complacent within the community of believers. Our true security rests in the combination of faith and fear, acknowledging our own weaknesses. We must not boast in our condition or forget our vulnerabilities, as this can lead to the temptation of sin. Instead, find confidence in God's promises and remain watchful, lest we fall from our position within the Church.
